text:
- Welcome to the
Executive Insights podcast,
brought to you by AWS.
My name is Jana Werner,

I'm with the Innovation
and Transformation team at AWS,

and I have the huge
pleasure of having here with me

Aleksy Zayet, you are
the Chief IT and Cloud Architect
for PrivatBank.
Welcome to our podcast.
Great to have you here.

Can you tell us a little
bit about what your role is
and what the role of PrivatBank
is for the Ukrainian country?
- Hi, Jana. Hi, everybody.

Thank you for the invitation,
it's a pleasure for me.
And I'm really from PrivatBank, Ukraine

and PrivatBank, the
largest bank in Ukraine.
We are a state-owned bank
and we are serving more than a half of our
Ukrainian population.

We provide classical banking
services like credit cards,
deposits, payments for our clients.

Also, we are famous by our
mobile banking application
called Privat24, which serves
more than 13 million of our clients.

- So more than half the
Ukrainian population depend

on your services and your
products and your support.
- Absolutely, we are quite important
for our financial system of the Ukraine.

- And things got quite
difficult on February '22,
didn't they?

Can you share a bit about the
situation as the war started

and what that meant for your
people and for your customers?
- Sure, at the end of February 2022,

unfortunately, a full-fledged
war came to Ukraine.
And our people,
we have very brave people in Ukraine,

but even in these
circumstances, they are scared.

We got a lot of losses of our
infrastructure in Ukraine.
We lost about $1 billion as damaged
or destroyed critical infrastructure.
Our financial metrics like GDP
reduced up to 45%

and our inflation rate
increased up to 30%.

But first of all, the
main priority for us was

to save our people, our
employees, and our customers.

- I guess it was a challenging
time for your people, right?

I think you told me you
did a lot to protect

and support them through
a very difficult time
and trying to keep your services going
for your customers as well.

- Sure, we protect our
people by relocating
to the western part of Ukraine,

where it was the most
safest place in Ukraine.

But unfortunately, we
don't have such places now.
And our people, especially head office,

are working from shelters,
bringing with them their kids
because our school almost closed.

And we are lucky because
our head office staff

had experienced how to work
remotely after the COVID period.

And that's why our operational
processes were not impacted.
But of course, this is very big stress
to our people every day.
Missiles attack every day,

searching for news about
changing on the front lines.
Every day we have these air alarms,

and of course, it's very
hard to our employees.
- I can imagine.

And I even saw when I
was with you yesterday,

you were checking missile
attacks on your phone
coming up, alerts coming up.
That's a whole different reality
that I can't even begin to grasp.

- Sure, unfortunately, this
is our business as usual now.
- Yeah.

It's a whole different
way of remote working
than what we're doing, from shelters.

After February, there
were a lot of attacks
on Ukrainian infrastructure.

So data centers, you showed
me photos of data centers

being destroyed, issues
with networking, internet.

How did you manage that and
how did you deal with that
in having in the back of your mind
that you need to support your customers?

They still need access
to their money somehow.
- Back in early 2022,

we had two data centers
on Ukrainian territory,

which provided services and
which hosted our IT systems.

So we had almost 1,000
of hardware servers,
which hosted up to
8,000 of our virtual machines
and stored 11 database of data,

so we are quite on-prem
based bank this time.

And when first missile
attacks started in February
and early March 2022,

we got two really close
to our data centers.

And we understood that
there are no safe places
which we can locate our IT infrastructure
in Ukrainian territory.
And we started considering some options,
how to protect our infrastructure,
and our clients, and our bank operations.
The first option was obviously
to relocate our equipment abroad,
but unfortunately we couldn't do it
because of a long period of downtime,

which is not acceptable
to leave our clients
without operations.

And the second option
was to run a data center
with equipment in Europe.
And this option was also not realized

because all the famous
providers of location
couldn't do it even in six months.

And that's why the last
option, which we consider it,
was migrate into cloud, to public cloud.

And because of the
previously used a small part
of AWS services for our banking,
digital banking applications,
we considered it to migrate to AWS.

But our national bank
regulator was strictly against
public cloud usage in banking systems.
And that's why we started negotiations
and requested to allow us to do it.

- You said, I think when
we chatted the other day,

you said that first
there was a long period

of being nervous about
cloud in your country
and in most countries.
And then with the start of the war,

a number of ministers met
and very quickly decided
that it's now time to do it, right?
- Sure, this is only one possible option

how to deploy such a large
scale infrastructure in weeks.

- You had said, you
told me you went to Kiev
and the city was completely empty.

You were the only one going
to Kiev and not away from Kiev
and got advice from the regulator to say,
"It's war. Go. Do it."
- Unfortunately, we had many scenarios

and we didn't seriously
consider the scenario,

which was a full scale invasion
will be in the first days
of the war near Kiev.
And we treated our Kiev data centers
as backup and protected one,
but its seems under attack at first.

- So the regulator gave you
the opportunity to say yes,
you can now go into cloud.
And then what did you do?
That's a massive, massive opportunity now
and a big change, right?
Overnight, basically.
- Exactly.
8th of March, 2022, we started

just after the regulator
allowed us to migrate.

We immediately, the same day,
started our cloud journey.
We work day and night

and we focused on, first of
all, critical applications,
then important applications.

And we started to go to
cloud, to rehost, reallocate,

lift and shift, do
whatever possible to deploy

as quick as possible our
infrastructure in cloud.

- And I still find it so
remarkable, I can't believe it.
You did this in 43 days.
- Yes, it was a world record.

Nobody migrated faster
than we, because we,
under the title of speed over perfection,

we started this migration
and the final goal

to provide reliable
services to our clients
as quick as possible.

That's why we have no
time, simply have no time

to design a landing zone,
to design architecture
to make our configuration more reliable
and more optimized.

And that's why we are working
just like we can work.

- So what was the original
timeframe when you...

Before February '22,
when you were planning
and thinking about if we go to cloud,
how long would this take?
What was your original estimate?

- I can say that we planned
because of regulation

didn't allow it, but
when we start migration,

we met with some companies
who had this experience,
who had experience and skilled guys
and migrated FSI companies to the cloud.

And for our scale, it was
about three years estimation
to make proper migration.
- So you went from three years to 43 days?

- Yes.
- [Jana] That's pretty impressive.

What kind of things have
accelerated your journey?
Obviously when I work with customers,
we find that it's very hard for them
to accelerate their time to value.

And clearly, you have
accelerated like crazy.
There's been a strong purpose there.

War, we know that things
like war and like pandemics

create a really strong
purpose so that people can go
and start doing speed over perfection.
We know that really good companies

and really good transformation
leaders can also create

this purpose without
these external conditions
by bringing together a really strong why
to do something new.

Why transform something that
speaks to hearts and minds,

something that paints a
different vision of the future
and that connects people
to wanting to move onto the journey.

You've had this, of course,
coming from the outside,

but I'm wondering what
are the kind of things
that our listeners can learn
how to accelerate a journey onto cloud
and in general, a transformation journey.

What are the things where you
say, "These are accelerants

that really work, whether you
are in your situation or not?"
- First of all, everybody who participated
in this migration understood priority
because we simply had no other choices

to protect our... Not
even banking operations,
even the country financial system.

That's why we understood that
this is priority number zero
and migrate 24/7, without weekends,
without nights, and people just shifting
and working every time.
- So one thing we know is that it works

when this classic challenge
that companies today have,
having too many priorities, reducing them,

focusing on them, and
moving forward with them.
It wasn't so easy, right?

There were some acceleration
killers as well.

I remember you saying that
when your leadership said,
"We're going to go to cloud,"
that some of the senior business leaders
were quite nervous about that, right?
- Yes.

Unfortunately, not everybody
from even IT management
believe that our system can work in cloud

without defactoring in such
a short period of time.

And that's why we nominated
a number of engineers,
even not managers, who started migrated
at the first line.

And when some of our important
system was deployed in cloud

and we switched a lot of our
customers and it works well,
it really highly motivated our teams
who didn't believe that it's possible
and they start working.
So this leading by example help other guys
to believe that it's possible.

- So showing quick
successes and that creates
support and ownership and, yeah,
support for people to try and do the same.
Brilliant.
What are some acceleration killers
that you came across in this journey
and how did you deal with them?
- Some people on team didn't believe
that we got approval from our management,

that cloud is not
secured, cloud is possible
we can lose control over our systems

and we calm them down and
said that even startups
can get approvals and can get budgets.

If we have a goal and we go
into the right direction,

after this migration, we did
everything compliance secured

and got every needed
approval, just post-factum.
And even this year,
we had a big audit from National Bank
and we successfully passed it
without any important findings.
- Brilliant.
- Our work is recognized.
- That's amazing.
So we talked first bit about clarity.

Clarity is an absolute
accelerant for transformation.

So understanding clarity
of why, and clarity of,
"I just have a few priorities,
I'm clear on them and I can move forward."
There's also a big part,

or another concept,
that's really important

to accelerate is about ownership,
giving people ownership.
Have you experienced that

or how did you experience
that on your journey,
and your cloud journey?
- Let's start from clarity.

When we started the migration,
we had everyday meetings

with our senior management
and engineer team every day,
even on weekends.

And an extreme focus from
our senior management,
of our CEO and CIO, to this project
to also help resolve blockers immediately,
to coordinate work more efficiently

and the team can ask
questions which they have
and explain good achievements
to share experience with others.
And this sharing experience,

it means clarity because
any of team members,

all of our team members
understand what's going on,

what's the priority,
what blockers others had,
and how they resolve it.
And it really helped,
and we even now, have this cloud meeting
three times per week.

And sharing experience,
coordinating projects,
help others who had some blockers.
- So it's another common theme that we see

for accelerating transformations
is having the executive
or leadership support, building their...
Coaching the team, enabling the team,
and moving blockers out of the way.
What about ownership?
You've shared with me some stories
about people really stepping up, right?
- Yes, just after migration,
we faced a big issue with our cost

because we underestimated
budget for cloud setup
up to four times.
And it was really shock to our management,

and we start to optimize
our systems and right size,
do proper configuration of our systems.

And we noticed that not all
part of our infrastructure
were covered by attention from IT guys.

And this is why we started
this dialogue about ownership.

We divide all our
landscape on applications

and define new role in
organization, IT application

owner responsible for whole
layers of application,
not only development or infrastructure,
understanding of cloud services,
understanding of security and aspects,
understanding of cost control.
This is the main duties of this new
assigned duties.
- Brilliant.

And so now that you've kind
of gone onto your journey,
you've moved into the cloud,
you've consolidated and optimized
and understood how to operate in cloud,

what can you do faster now
that you couldn't do before?
- I didn't believe that we can do
faster than we did it. But probably....
we didn't have a super experienced team,
and we had only five or six

IT architects and engineers
who had experience with AWS.
And of course, education of team.

If we know that this
migration could happen,

we start to educate our
people much earlier.

And I think it can positively
increase speed of migration,
but our achievement also, I think,
acceptable in our circumstances.
- And what things can you do faster
now that you are in the cloud?

What can you deliver
quicker for customers,
products and services?
- On top of reliability and security,
which we got after this cloud migration
as an additional benefit,

we, for our business, got the
additional benefit of agility

and now we can deploy
our systems for pilot

or for scaling and our
production load faster.

Even in hours, not in months,
like it was previously
with on-prem infrastructure.

And I had a good example,
even from this week,

President of Ukraine
announced a new program

to support our citizens
in this hard winter period
with additional refunds.

And we had to open special
cards for all our customers.
And we opened,

during the first hours
of this project started,
more than one million cards.

- Unbelievable. That's
very impressive, wow.

Congratulations.
- Thank you.
- Awesome.

Your transformation journey
has taken you from,
let's just quickly land on the cloud.
Let's consolidate it
and learn what it's like once we're there
and find our bearings.

And now you are massively
moving on into innovation.

So you started to do a
lot with generative AI.
Can you share a bit what you're doing
and how you created the curiosity
for people to go and work and experiment,
which is, so curiosity is first the other
or the third of the three accelerators,
the clarity, ownership, but curiosity

is really important too
to support and learn
and find new ways and experiment.
What are your people doing in that space?
- The next enabler from our cloud,
as a side effect of our cloud journey,

it was a possibility to
use AI services from AWS,

it was not possible with
on-prem infrastructure at all.
And we start looking for new opportunities

and business cases using
this AI technologies now.

And we, after this tough
optimization waves,

we control every penny
of our infrastructure.

But for AI services,
we had a carte blanche

and all teams can experiment,
can pilot, can check tests,
validate services, and on top of it,
we invest a lot to educate our people,
to find additional possibilities,

how to implement and
use the AI technologies.
And we had few examples from this year,
as many companies, we started and created
our internal chatbot,

which helps the understanding
of our knowledge base
and providing information to employees
and to reduce time to customer service
and customer consultation.
Also, we implement some AI services
in financial monitoring and anti-fraud.

And now we converting speech
to text claims in fraud

from our clients and we
reduce a lot of workloads
and time,

manual time from employees
who listen to these records
and making some conclusions.
So that's why we did it now automatically

with our really high
acceptance rate up to 90%.
- Amazing.

So curiosity you're supporting
by giving people the mandate,

by pointing at the topics
that you want to focus on,
generative AI, what can we do with it?
How can we get to value?
And by getting leadership support to say,
"Focus on this, you don't have restraints,
you can experiment and you can learn."

- Exactly.
- Yeah.

And lastly, you shared with
me a whole different meaning
of what a KPI is.
Can you share this with our audience,

because I think it's
another brilliant example
of how you create clarity and ownership
and inside curiosity.

- Yes, our management
established new understanding
of KPI word.

KPI, it means "keep people
inspired, keep people informed",
and we use it to motivate our people
to increase their efficiency.
When people understand what's going on
or in which directions we are moving
and what achievements we expect,
they work much more efficiently
than without this understanding.
- You mentioned you have regular meetings
where the entire staff can take part?
- Yes, and not entire.
We have this core team of cloud projects
and IT management on this meeting,

but we had a recording of
this meeting and meeting notes
and many of our IT guys look into it.
And even when they accidentally met me,
they asked about some decision requesting
to participate in some projects.
So it really works.

- Creates curiosity and
also creates transparency,
which is another good accelerator,
when people understand what's going on,
when they know where to learn,
when they know what focus is,

then they can get on with
working towards your outcomes.
Yeah, awesome.

Well, thank you so much for
sharing your remarkable,
remarkable story.

Wish you all the best going
into your innovation journey now

and of course we also hope
and wish of all the best
for all the people in Ukraine
and that the situation stabilizes.
Thank you so much for coming,

making this very
difficult way coming here,
crossing the border, coming to the US,
your first time in the US as well, right?

- Yes.
- Awesome.
Are you enjoying it?

- Absolutely.
- Brilliant.
Thank you so much. Thanks a lot.
- Thank you.

I wish everybody a
successful transformation

without war.
- Absolutely.

Thanks a lot.
- Thank you.
